o: Multi-Factor Authentication: Requiring 2 or more distinct factors (Know, Have, Are) to verify identity.

q: What are the 3 main factors of authentication?
o: Something you Know (Password), Something you Have (Token), Something you Are (Biometric).
A secret stored in your memory. e.g. Password, PIN, Security Question answer.
A physical object you possess. e.g. Smartphone, Hardware Token, Smart Card.
Biometric characteristics. e.g. Fingerprint, Iris Scan, Facial Recognition.
2FA is a subset of MFA requiring exactly 2 factors. MFA can require 2 or more.

q: Why is SMS OTP considered weak?
o: Vulnerable to SIM Swapping and SS7 interception. NIST deprecates it. Not Phishing resistant.
Attacker tricks carrier into transferring victim's phone number to attacker's SIM card to intercept OTPs.
Algorithm generating temporary codes based on Current Time and a Shared Secret (Seed). changes every 30s.
Algorithm generating codes based on a Counter (incremented on each use) and a Shared Secret.

q: What is the 'Shared Secret' in TOTP/HOTP?
o: A cryptographic key (Seed) known only to the Server and the Authenticator App. Used to calculate codes.

q: Purpose of QR Code in TOTP setup?
o: Transfers the Shared Secret (Seed) from Server to Authenticator App conveniently.
Server sends a 'Approve/Deny' prompt to a registered mobile device app. User taps Approve.
Attacker spams victim with Push requests (at 2am), hoping victim taps 'Approve' just to make it stop.
Number Matching. User must type a number shown on the login screen into the Push prompt to prove presence.
MFA that cryptographically binds the auth attempt to the specific Domain (e.g. FIDO/WebAuthn). Prevents Credential harvesting.

q: Why is TOTP not Phishing Resistant?
o: User can be tricked into typing the 6-digit code into a fake site (Evilginx). Attacker relays it to real site.
Physical device that generates OTPs or performs FIDO challenges. Highest security assurance.
Universal 2nd Factor. Open standard for using USB/NFC security keys as a second factor.
Classic MFA (SMS/TOTP) can be intercepted by MITM. FIDO/WebAuthn prevents MITM by checking origin.
Stealing a valid Session Cookie allows attacker to bypass MFA entirely (Session Hijacking).
Static set of one-time use codes given at enrollment. Used if primary MFA method is lost.
Time allowed for a new user to set up MFA. Risk: Attacker compromises password and sets up MFA before user.
Sets a persistent cookie often valid for 30+ days. If device is stolen, attacker has access without MFA.
Device identified by cert/fingerprint that suppresses MFA prompts. Should be Managed/Compliant.
Only prompting for MFA when risk is high (New IP, New Device, Geo-velocity). Reduces friction.
Re-prompting for MFA when user attempts a sensitive action (Change Password, Wire Transfer) even if logged in.
Bad practice. 'Mother's maiden name' is 'Something you Know', but low entropy and public. Don't use.
Low-tech MFA. User looks up coordinates (B5) on a printed card. Physical 'Something you Have'.
Verifying identity via a SEPARATE communication channel (Network) than the login request (e.g. Login on PC, Verify on Phone).
Susceptible to Deepfake Voice spoofing and Vishing (Voice Phishing). Accessibility feature but risky.
Phishing framework that acts as a transparent reverse proxy. Captures Password AND Session Cookie (bypassing MFA).
AI mimicking a user's voice to bypass Voice Biometrics or trick Helpdesk into resetting MFA.
Flaw in global telecom network allowing attackers to intercept SMS messages intended for victim.
Binding auth tokens to the specific TLS connection (Client Cert). Prevents stolen tokens/cookies being used elsewhere.
EU regulation requiring MFA for payments. Requires 'Dynamic Linking' (Auth code bound to Amount + Payee).
The OTP/Code generated must be specific to the transaction details. If Amount changes, Code is invalid.
System wrongly matches a stranger to your account. Security failure.
System fails to recognize YOU. Usability failure (Frustration).
You cannot change your fingerprint/retina if it is compromised/stolen. It's compromised forever.
Transforming biometric data (Hashing/Salting) so original image can't be reconstructed. Allows 'Resetting' the template.
Constantly verifying user (e.g. via keystroke dynamics, gait, smartwatch) throughout the session, not just at start.
Software-based OTP generator (App). Depends on security of the phone OS.
Dedicated hardware device (Key fob) for OTPs. Harder to hack remotely.
Using MFA (e.g. Hardware Token) on a system disconnected from internet. Token generates code locally.
Replaces passwords with strong 2FA on device. Uses TPM + PIN/Bio. Keys never leave device.
Behavioral Biometric. Identifying user by typing rhythm (Flight time between keys).
Behavioral biometric based on how a person walks (detected by phone accelerometer).
Standard protocol used by VPNs/Firewalls to talk to MFA Servers (e.g. NPS, Duo Proxy).
If Google Account is compromised, attacker gets all MFA seeds. Convenience vs Security trade-off.
If User device clock or Server clock drifts, code won't match. Servers use a 'Window' to allow slight drift.
Crucial to prevent Brute Forcing a 6-digit code (1 million combos). Lock after 5 tries.
Cannot interactive MFA. Use Certificates, Keys, or Managed Identity instead. NOT passwords.
Emergency account. Should rely on FIDO key stored in physical safe, not phone (might be down).
Hardened laptop dedicated for Admin tasks. MFA required to log in to PAW.
Using GPS/IP to verify user is in expected location (Somewhere you Are - Extended).
Login from London at 9am, login from Tokyo at 10am. Physically impossible. Trigger Alert/MFA.
Software MFA (Push, TOTP, SMS). High assurance.
Hardware Crypto MFA (FIDO Key). Very High assurance. Phishing resistant.
Relying on Google/Facebook MFA. If their account is hacked, your app is accessed. Trust delegation.
Critical. RDP is #1 ransomware entry vector. Must enforce MFA (Duo/Hello) for remote access.
Exploiting vulnerabilities in the global SS7 telecom signaling protocol to intercept SMS messages and calls remotely.
Attack using a hidden S@T Browser on the SIM card to instruct the phone to send location/data without user knowledge.
Automated bot service (sold on Telegram) that calls victims posing as 'Bank Security' to trick them into reading out their OTP.
Using signals like Geolocation, IP Reputation, Time of Day, and Device Health to determine if MFA is needed or should be blocked.
Security rule flagging logins from two distant locations (e.g. NY and London) in a timeframe shorter than physical travel allows.
Analyzing passive patterns like typing speed (keystroke dynamics), mouse movements, and screen angle to identify the user.
Collecting data (OS, Browser version, Screen resolution, Fonts) to identify a specific device without using Cookies.
Browser API (navigator.credentials) allowing web apps to create and use public-key credentials (FIDO) for auth.
Data sent during registration proving the Authenticator Model (e.g. 'I am a YubiKey 5') and its trust anchor.
Credential stored PERSISTENTLY on the Authenticator. Allows 'Username-less' login (User puts in key, key tells site who they are).
Authenticator built into the device (e.g. TouchID on Mac, Windows Hello, FaceID on iPhone). Cannot be removed.
Portable authenticator (e.g. YubiKey, Titan Key) that can be used across multiple devices (via USB/NFC).
CTAP1 = U2F (2nd factor only). CTAP2 = FIDO2 (Passwordless, Resident Keys, PIN support).
UP = Touching the key (proving human). UV = PIN or Biometric (proving authorized user). UV is stronger.
Attacker forces system to fallback to a weaker method (e.g. 'I lost my Key, send SMS') to bypass strong auth.
Attacker steals the Private Signing Key of the IdP (AD FS) and mints 'Golden' tokens to bypass MFA and impersonate anyone.
Stealing the Azure AD PRT from a compromised device to gain persistent SSO access without re-authenticating.
Emergency Admin account excluded from standard MFA rules (or using different MFA) to ensure access if IdP/MFA fails.
Authenticating to a PC when offline. Must rely on cached credentials or Hardware Token (Smart Card/YubiKey). Cloud MFA won't work.
Smart Cards used by US Govt/Military. Contain PKI certificates. Require Physical Card + PIN (2FA).
Client Certificate acts as 'Something you Have'. Often combined with PIN (Know) for 2FA.
Linux framework to insert MFA steps (e.g. generic-totp) into the login process (SSH/Sudo).
Legacy protocol used by VPNs. Often sends password in cleartext (PAP) or weak hash. Vulnerable if not tunneled.
Legacy NIST term (1-4) describing confidence in identity. Replaced by IAL, AAL, FAL in 800-63-3.
Property of FIDO. The server (verifier) never sees the private key/password, so a fake server can't steal it to use elsewhere.
Ideally, keys in hardware (SE/TPM) cannot be exported or cloned. Prevents attacker creating a duplicate key.
Dedicated secure coprocessor for handling Biometrics and Keys. Isolated from main OS (iOS/macOS).
Google's secure element in Pixel phones. Verifies Verified Boot and stores Protected Keys.
Industry standard chip for secure crypto storage (BitLocker keys, Windows Hello keys) and integrity attestation.
Device proves to MDM (Intune) that it booted securely (Secure Boot, TPM) and has no rootkits before getting access.
Using Cloud MFA (Azure MFA) to protect On-Prem resources (VPN/Radius) via an NPS Extension/Proxy.
What You See Is What You Sign. Displaying transaction details on the secure hardware device itself (e.g. Ledger) to prevent malware spoofing.
Project by Google to test crypto libraries (including FIDO implementations) against known attacks.
CBOR encoded data returned by Authenticator creation. Contains authData and attestation statement.
Byte array containing flags (UP, UV), counter, and sometimes the Public Key. Signed by the authenticator.
Process of creating a key pair. 1. Server sends Challenge + User info. 2. Authenticator signs it. 3. Server stores Public Key.
Process of logging in. 1. Server sends Challenge. 2. Authenticator signs Challenge with Private Key. 3. Server verifies signature.
The domain name (e.g. google.com) claiming the credential. Browser enforces that RP ID matches actual domain (Anti-Phishing).
Opaque byte sequence identifying the user account on the RP. Stored on the Authenticator for Resident Keys. Not PII.
FIDO2 extension allowing RP to enforce a minimum PIN length on the authenticator.
RP tells authenticator 'I don't need PIN/Bio, just touch is fine'. Reduces friction for low-risk actions.
RP mandates PIN or Biometric verification. If authenticator can't do it, auth fails. High security.
End-to-End encrypted sync of FIDO credentials between user's own devices. Makes Passkeys recoverable and convenient.
New capability to securely send a copy of a Passkey to a contact nearby. Useful for shared accounts (e.g. Netflix).
Cloud Assisted BLE. Allows using a Phone (FIDO) to log in to a PC (Browser) by scanning a QR code.

q: QR Code Phishing protection in FIDO?
o: The Hybrid flow requires the Phone and PC to be physically close (verified via Bluetooth Advertisements) to prevent remote phishing.
Allows storing a small amount of extra data (blob) alongside the credential on the authenticator.
Allows storing larger data (e.g. Certificate) on the authenticator. Read/Written only after User Verification.
Used for 'Registration Lock'. Prevents SIM Swapper from registering your number on a new device without the PIN.
A 6-digit PIN required when registering phone number again. Prevents hijack via SMS interception.
Legacy solution for apps (Mail clients) that don't support Modern Auth (MFA). Generates a random pwd per app. Bypass MFA.
Replaces Basic Auth. Supports MFA, Tokens, and Conditional Access. Outlook/Mail apps use this now.
Sends Username/Password on every request. Weak to replay/interception. Doesn't support MFA easily. Being deprecated.
MFA is the primary defense against Password Spraying. Even if password is guessed, attacker is blocked.
Often the 'Weakest Link'. If Attacker can reset password via Email and remove MFA via 'Lost phone' flow, MFA is bypassed.
User designates friends (Trustees). To recover account, n of m friends must send a code. Prevents single-point social engineering.
Crucial. Root account (AWS Root, Linux Root) has unlimited power. Must be protected by Hardware MFA (safe storage).
Software-based MFA (Authenticator App) acting as a virtual token. Cheaper/easier than Hardware, but device dependent.
Devs using AWS CLI/Git need MFA too. Implemented via temporary Session Tokens (STS) obtained after MFA code entry.
API call to exchange long-term Access Keys + MFA Code for short-term temporary credentials (AccessKey, SecretKey, SessionToken).
Condition where assuming a high-privilege Role (e.g. Admin) REQUIRES the user to have authenticated with MFA recently.
Allowing a user to skip MFA for a short period (e.g. 1 hour) after successful check. Balances security vs annoyance.
Traffic coming from known Tor endpoint. High risk of anonymity/malice. Should trigger MFA or Block.
Device security model compromised. Malware can steal MFA secrets/keys stored in keychain. Banking apps often block this.
Detecting if app is running in a Simulator (Android Studio). often used by attackers to script automated login attempts.
Principle: 'Never Trust, Always Verify'. MFA required for EVERY access request, regardless of network location (Intranet vs Internet).
Notorious for spamming MFA Push notifications (MFA Fatigue) and buying Session Cookies/Passwords from Info Stealers.
Expert at Social Engineering Helpdesks to reset MFA and SIM Swapping. Targeted Casinos (MGM/Caesars).
Protocol for securing online card payments with MFA. Supports 'Frictionless' (Risk analysis) vs 'Challenge' (OTP/Bio).
Ensuring the biometric source is a live human, not a photo/mask/video (Anti-Spoofing). Checks for blinking, depth, texture.
ISO standard term for detecting spoofing attempts (Printed photos, 3D masks, Voice recordings) on biometric sensors.
Iteratively feeding slightly modified images to a matcher to improve the score until acceptance. Requires score feedback.
Match-on-Card: Biometric template never leaves the Smart Card (Privacy). Match-on-Server: Template sent to central DB (Risk of leak).
Synthetic face images generated to match a large percentage of the population's face templates (like a Master Key).
Scanning blood vessel patterns (Palm/Finger) using Near-Infrared light. Very hard to spoof vs Fingerprint.
Iris: Colored ring, stable from infancy, non-contact. Retina: Blood vessels at back of eye, changes with disease, intrusive scan.
Classified as 'Special Category' (Sensitive) data. Processing requires Explicit Consent or substantial public interest.
FIDO keys generate a unique Key Pair for EACH website (RP). Sites cannot collude to track user across domains via the Key.
Revealing the exact model/serial of the authenticator to the RP. Could be used for tracking/fingerprinting the user.
System to store crypto keys in a trusted container (often TEE). Hard for malware to extract keys.
High-security physical appliance for generating/storing crypto keys. Used by CAs and Banks for root of trust.
Formal, scripted procedure for generating Root CA keys. Involves witnesses, video recording, air-gapped HSMs, safe deposit boxes.
Splitting a Recovery Seed into N parts (e.g. 5). Need K parts (e.g. 3) to reconstruct. 'M of N' control.
Authentication without a knowledge factor (Password). Uses Possession (Device) + Inherence (Bio/PIN) (FIDO2).
No. It is typically Multi-Factor: Device (Have) + Local PIN/Bio (Know/Are). Just verified locally.
Relies entirely on Email security. If email is hacked, attacker enters. Also links can be intercepted/cached by proxies.
Desktop shows QR. Mobile App (already auth'd) scans it. Mobile sends session token to Desktop via Server. Convenient.
Using phone proximity to unlock a laptop. 'Something you Have'. Convenience factor, generally low security alone.
Process of verifying a REAL LIVE person owns the claimed identity. e.g. Upload Driver's License + Selfie Video check.
Scanning the Machine Readable Zone on Passports/IDs to detect tampering/forgeries during generic identity verification.
Injecting a pre-recorded Deepfake video stream into the camera feed of a KYC app to bypass Selfie check.
Asking 'What was your car in 2010?'. Answerable by data brokers/attackers. Considered weak (NIST Restricted).
IdP puts 'amr' (Authentication Method Reference) in the token to tell the App HOW user authenticated (e.g. 'pwd', 'mfa', 'fido').
User is logged in (Level 1). Attempts Transfer > $1000. App forces re-auth with FIDO (Level 2) before allowing.
Browser feature where Passkeys appear in the Username autofill dropdown. User selects account -> Bios -> Logged in.
User visits a URL (displayed on TV) on their Phone/PC and enters a code to authorize the TV app. Avoids typing usually difficult passwords on TV.
Phishing via QR codes in emails/PDFs. Scanners bypass email filters (which scan text/links). Victim scans -> fake site.
Attack where proxy sits between User and Real Site. Relays credentials and MFA codes in real-time. Captures Session Cookie.
No. User types code into AiTM site, attacker relays it to real site instantly. Login succeeds, attacker gets cookie.
No. Attacker triggers Push. User sees prompt and approves (thinking it's them). Attacker gets in.
FIDO / WebAuthn. The protocol verifies the 'Origin' (Domain). Fake AiTM domain won't match. Browser refuses to sign.
Hardware keys have limited storage (25-50 passkeys). Need to manage/delete old ones. Modern Passkeys in Cloud have no limit.
To prevent tracking individual users, thousands of YubiKeys share the same 'Batch' Private Key for attestation.
Using a FIDO credential on a Phone to sign in on a nearby Laptop (via QR/BLE handshake).
Using iPhone/Android as a FIDO authenticator. Leverages built-in Secure Enclave and Biometrics.
RISC-V based secure chip in Pixel. Resistant to advanced physical attacks (Voltage glitching, Laser fault injection).
Probability that the system incorrectly accepts an unauthorized person (Security Failure). 1 in 1,000,000 for FaceID.
Probability that the system incorrectly rejects an authorized person (Usability Failure). Annoying for user.
Point where FAR and FRR are equal. Used to compare accuracy of different biometric systems. Lower is better.
User must type a 2-digit number displayed on the browser into the Push notification. Prevents MFA Fatigue/Accidental approval.
Alert triggered when login comes from an IP associated with Botnets, Tor, or a country user never visited.
MFA renders password spraying useless. Even if they guess 'Password123!', they can't pass MFA.
MFA stops attackers using leaked Username/Password pairs from other breaches. They lack the 2nd factor.
Generally No. If attacker steals the Session Cookie (post-MFA), they are 'logged in' as the user without re-doing MFA.
Demonstrating Proof-of-Possession. Binds Access Tokens to a private key held by the client. Stolen token is useless without key.
deducing crypto keys by analyzing power consumption or electromagnetic emissions of the hardware token during operation.
Using a device with hundreds of SIM cards to bypass international interconnect rates or generate fake OTP traffic.
Attackers generate massive volumes of SMS OTP requests to premium rate numbers they control, draining victim's budget.
Malware draws a fake window ON TOP of a legitimate banking app to trick user into entering credentials/OTP.
Malicious app requests 'Notification Access' permission to read incoming SMS OTPs/Push codes directly from notification bar.
Malware monitors clipboard. When user copies OTP/Password manager password, malware reads or replaces it.
Combining real (SSN) and fake (Name/Address) info to create a new identity. Used to open accounts/credit.
Bank account used to launder stolen funds. Often opened with stolen/synthetic identities.
Monitoring rate of actions (e.g. 5 password resets in 1 minute). High velocity implies automated attack.
Prepaid/Disposable phones. Hard to trace. Often used by attackers for SMS verification.
Virtual numbers (Google Voice). Easy to mass-generate. Often blocked by services requiring 'Real Mobile' for MFA.
Analyzing mouse curves, touch pressure, sensor data (accelerometer) to distinguish Human vs Bot without a captcha.
Requiring client to solve a computational puzzle before submitting form. Slows down bots/DDoS. Frictionless for humans.
Critical data exfiltration risk. Should ALWAYS prompt for fresh MFA verification before allowing bulk export.
If attacker adds their device, they get persistence. Must verify intent with current MFA device first.
Should be printed or stored in a Password Manager. NOT screenshot saved on the same phone (Single Point of Failure).
Helpdesk should trigger a Push Notification to the user's known app/device. User taps 'Yes - I am calling'.
Requiring user's manager to approve an MFA reset request via Email/Slack. Adds human verification layer.
Weakness. If Google account is hacked, attacker reads SMS. Also not a true 'Possession' factor (just a cloud inbox).
Locking account after 5 failed passwords prevents Brute Force, but creates DoS risk. Smart Lockout (Azure) only locks bad IPs.
CAPTCHA proves 'Human vs Bot'. MFA proves 'Identity'. CAPTCHA is often used BEFORE password to stop spraying.
Temporary lockout (e.g. 15 mins) after failures. Slows down attacker without requiring Admin intervention.
Cloud feature that counts failures from bad IPs differently than valid user IPs. Prevents attackers from locking out real users.
Allowing users to reset forgotten passwords IF they pass strong MFA (e.g. Phone + Email). Reduces Helpdesk calls.
Admin rules defining WHICH MFA methods are allowed (e.g. 'FIDO only for Admins', 'SMS allowed for Users').
Restricted due to risk of Interception (SS7) and SIM Swapping. Should only be used if no other option exists.
If codes sync to Cloud (Google/iCloud), a compromise of the Cloud Account exposes all MFA seeds. Convenience vs Security.
Register at least 2 Keys (Primary + Backup). Keep Backup in a safe. FIDO keys cannot be cloned/copied.
Improves UX by mostly being invisible. Only prompts for MFA when Risk is detected (New ID, Location, Behavior).
Automated reports showing 'Users at Risk', 'Risky Sign-ins', and 'Leaked Credentials'. Helps admins prioritize.
Period (e.g. 14 days) where users are nudged to set up MFA but not forced. Reduces support impact during rollout.
Systematically prompting users to set up 'Microsoft Authenticator' instead of SMS to improve security posture.
Answers (Mother's maiden name, High School) are easily found on Social Media or Data Breaches. Not 'Secret' anymore.
Phishing-resistant passwordless auth using a loopback server/crypto binding on the device. Replaces OTPs.
High. Private key stored in TPM (Hardware). Unlock requires PIN/Bio. Key never leaves device. Specific to that device.
128-bit identifier indicating the type/model of the Authenticator (e.g. 'YubiKey 5 NFC'). sent during registration.
Tells OS how to protect the credential (e.g. 'require UV to read'). Prevents malware from using resident keys silently.
Pseudo-Random Function. Allows deriving a symmetric encryption key from the FIDO authentication. Used for encrypted vaults (Bitwarden).
Random string sent by Server. Authenticator signs it. Prevents Replay Attacks.
Browser ensures the 'origin' (URL) initiating the call matches the RP ID. Prevents phishing sites from using your key.
User can delete Passkey from their device/cloud. Server (RP) must also provide a way to 'Unregister' keys in Account Settings.
Logging into a laptop with no internet. Duo App generates offline Passcode (HOTP). Push won't work.
Authenticating using an X.509 Client Certificate (Smart Card/Device Cert). Highly secure, Phishing resistant.
Managing Certificate Arbiters (CA) in the cloud (Intune/Scepman) to issue certs to devices over the air.
RDP itself doesn't support MFA natively well. Best done via RD Gateway (NPS/MFA extension) or IdP (Azure AD).
Configuring PAM (pam_google_authenticator.so) in sshd_config to require 'keyboard-interactive' code + Public Key.
Granting Admin rights only for a specific duration (e.g. 2 hours) after MFA + Approval. Reduces attack surface.
Azure service to manage/monitor JIT access. 'Eligible' roles require 'Activation' (MFA/Reason) to become 'Active'.
Non-human identity (App). Cannot do MFA. Must protect Client Secret/Cert carefully (Key Vault). Rotate often.
Allowing GitHub Actions/AWS to auth to Azure AD using OIDC Tokens (Trust) instead of storing secrets. Safer.
Scanning code repos for accidental commits of API Keys/Secrets. Early detection prevents abuse.
Open source tool to hunt for high-entropy strings (Secrets) in git history.
Private Signing Key should be in an HSM. Access to sign requires MFA + Approval. Prevents malware signing.
Framework ensuring build integrity. High levels require signed provenance, isolated builds, and 2-person review.
Users signing up for SaaS apps (Dropbox, Trello) with corporate email but NO SSO/MFA. Invisible risk.
By centralizing auth to one IdP (Okta/Azure), you can enforce MFA ONCE for thousands of apps.
1-3% of users approve malicious pushes. Attackers spam until success. Remediation: Number Matching.
Sending fake phishing emails to employees to train them. Should include 'Attacker-in-the-Middle' scenarios.
Ethical hackers testing if they can bypass MFA via Social Engineering, Session Hijacking, or Legacy protocols.

q: What is the primary risk of SMS MFA?
o: SIM Swapping (Attacker transfers phone number to their SIM).

q: Which MFA factor is 'Something you are'?

o: Uses current time + shared secret key to generate a code. Standardized in RFC 6238.
The point where False Acceptance Rate (FAR) and False Rejection Rate (FRR) meet. Lower CER = Better system.
WebAuthn (Browser API) and CTAP (Protocol for external authenticators).
Public Key Cryptography. Private key stays on device. Public key key registered with server.
The browser verifies the domain (origin) matches the key's credentials. Phishing sites (evil.com) cannot use google.com keys.
OTP inputs a text string (Phishable). FIDO uses cryptographic challenge-response (Phishing Resistant).
Resident Keys (Discoverable Credentials). The key stores the UserID/Handle, so you don't even need to type a username.
Flag in WebAuthn telling the authenticator to verify the user via PIN or Biometric (Local Auth).
Flag indicating user simply 'touched' the key (Proves human presence, but not specific identity).
Proof that the key is a genuine model (e.g. YubiKey 5) from a trusted manufacturer.
Attacker spams MFA requests. User gets annoyed and finally accepts one to stop the noise.
Number Matching. User must type a number displayed on the login screen into the app.
Authenticator Attestation GUID. Identifies the model/batch of the FIDO authenticator.
Hardware tokens keys are non-exportable. Software token seeds (QR codes) can be intercepted/copied.
Event-based. Code changes on every button press (Counter). Can get out of sync with server.
If button pressed too many times without login, counter drifts beyond 'look-ahead window'. Resync needed.
Static set of 10 one-time use codes given when setting up MFA. Critical for recovery if device lost.
Emergency Admin account excluded from MFA policies and Conditional Access. Used if Identity System breaks.
If-This-Then-That rules for Auth. 'If User=Admin AND Location=Foreign -> Require MFA'.
System calculates Risk Score. Low Risk -> No MFA. High Risk -> Challenge MFA. Better UX.
Login from London at 10AM and login from Tokyo at 11AM. Physically impossible -> Block/Challenge.
Generally weak. If email is compromised, MFA is bypassed. Access to email often doesn't prove identity well.
AI synthesizing user's voice to trick Helpdesk into resetting MFA. New vector for social engineering.
Attacker tricks carrier into porting victim's number to attacker's SIM. Intercepts all SMS OTPs.
Authentication happens over a different channel than the primary connection (e.g. Internet -> Phone Call).
Real-time MitM (Evilginx) can proxy the MFA page and capture the Token/Cookie. OTP/Push doesn't stop this.
Channel Binding (FIDO2 / Certificate). The auth is securely bound to the TLS connection/Domain.
Certificate-based hardware token. Requires PIN. Extremely secure, used by Gov/Military.
High FAR means impostors can log in. Security failure.
High FRR means legitimate users are blocked. Productivity/Support cost.
Feature in Bio scanners to distinguish live skin from silicone masks or photos.
Specific details (ridge endings/bifurcations) mapped from a fingerprint. Template stores these, not the image.
Tracking typing rhythm, mouse movements, gait. 'Continuous' authentication.
Projects 30,000 infrared dots (Structured Light) to map 3D face depth. Harder to spoof than 2D camera.
Low SAR/FAR requirements. Allowed for Crypto/Payments. Class 1 (Convenience) is not.
Replaces multiple passwords with strong 2FA on device. Key in TPM + PIN/Bio.
PIN that unlocks the key stored in TPM. PIN is local to device. Not sent to server.

q: Why is PIN safer than Password?
o: PIN is tied to the specific device (TPM). Password works everywhere. Stolen PIN is useless without device.
Usually 10 codes. Once used, it is invalid. Must generate new set when low.
Digital Identity Guidelines. Defines AALs (Authenticator Assurance Levels).
Provides high confidence that the claimant controls authenticator(s) bound to the subscribers account. (e.g. Software OTP).
Very high confidence. Requires HARDWARE cryptographic authenticator (FIPS 140) + Protection against Verifier Impersonation.
Assurance that the Verifier (Server) cannot use your credentials to impersonate you elsewhere (e.g. PKI/FIDO).
Challenging. Requires locally cached credentials/claims or TOTP verified by Agent on PC (e.g. Duo Offline).
Using Hardware Tokens (TOTP/HOTP) where the seed is manually imported to the air-gapped server.
Splitting a secret (e.g. Root Key) into N parts, requiring M parts to reconstruct. Ultimate Multi-person Auth.
Parties jointly compute a function (Signature) over their inputs while keeping those inputs private. No single key exists.
Digital signature that requires t of n signers to cooperate. Output is a valid signature.
Vulnerability in global telecom network allowing attackers to intercept SMS/Calls globally just by knowing phone number.

q: Why SMS is still used despite risks?
o: Ubiquity. Works on every phone (dumb or smart) without app installation. Low barrier to entry.
Service calls user and hangs up immediately. App verifies the LAST CALLER ID matches the service number. No code typing.
Server sends hints ('client-device', 'hybrid') to Browser to help it choose the right authenticator UI.
Using QR Code + Bluetooth to use a Phone as a Security Key for a PC (CaBLE - Cloud Assisted Bluetooth Low Energy).
Cloud Assisted Bluetooth LE. Protocol for phone-to-pc passkey usage (scan QR on PC, phone connects via BLE).
High. The underlying private key is bound to the domain (rpId). Fake site cannot invoke the key.
Using a FIDO credential on one device (Phone) to sign in on another (Laptop) via QR/Bluetooth.
Reveals device unique ID. Browsers often block it unless device is managed/policy permitted.
Allows keys to provide persistent identifiers to the RP, useful for asset tracking in corps.
Allows users to View/Update/Delete resident keys stored on the authenticator via the Browser/OS UI.
Enterprise Policy forcing FIDO keys to ALWAYS prompt for PIN/Bio, even if RP sets uv='discouraged'.
Usually 4. Enterprise policy can enforce longer (e.g. 6) on supported keys (YubiKey 5.4+).
Preventing '1234' or '1111'. Enforced by Authenticator firmware or Client.
Protocol allowing OS (Settings) to manage fingerprints on the external key. (e.g. Add Finger to YubiKey Bio).
Linux framework. MFA is added via a module (pam_google_authenticator.so or pam_duo.so).
Directive to chain auth methods. 'publickey,keyboard-interactive' requires Key AND MFA code.
Google is basic TOTP. MS Auth supports Push, Passwordless (Phone Sign-in), and Cloud Backup.
Multi-device sync. Cloud backup (encrypted). Desktop app (deprecated).
Open Source authenticator by Red Hat. Supports TOTP/HOTP. No cloud sync (strictly local).
Uses proprietary protocol over HTTPS to Duo Cloud. Cloud pushes to Apple/Google. App pops up. User taps Approve. Duo Cloud talks to SP.
Newer OIDC-based interface. Redirects to Duo-hosted page instead of iFrame. More secure.
For Windows Logon. If PC offline, use 'Offline Code' generated in Duo App (HOTP-like).
Service Accounts (Servers) can't press buttons. Exclude them from MFA policy using 'Group' or 'Identity Type' filter.
Real-time risk of the specific auth attempt (Anonymous IP, Impossible Travel, Malicious IP).
Long-term risk of the Identity itself. (Leaked credentials found on Dark Web, History of bad behavior).
Force Password Change (Secure Password Change). Just MFA is not enough if password is leaked.
Block or Require MFA (Step-up). If user passes MFA, risk might be dismissed (or confirmed compromised).
Defining Office IP ranges as 'Trusted'. Can bypass MFA (risky - internal threat) or reduce risk score.
Guests (External) should perform MFA in the Resource Tenant (Your comp) OR trust MFA from their Home Tenant (Cross-tenant access settings).
Configuring 'Trust MFA from external Azure AD'. Prevents double-prompting guests (MFA at home, MFA at resource).
Forcing users to register for MFA (Combined Info) immediately upon login, before they trigger a risk policy.
Dedicated, locked-down laptop for Admin tasks. Checking email/browsing web is blocked. MFA required to log in.
Opening RDP/SSH ports (3389/22) on NSG only for a requested time window, for a specific source IP, after MFA.
PaaS service allowing RDP/SSH via Browser (HTML5) over TLS 443. No public IP on VM needed. MFA enforced at Portal.
User enters 'password' + 'push' or 'password,code' in the password field. VPN concentrator talks to NPS/MFA Adapter.
Modern approach. VPN Client opens embedded browser to IdP (Azure/Okta). Supports rich MFA (FIDO/Push/Number Match).
If User Device clock is off by 2 mins, code is invalid. NTP sync is critical for TOTP.
Physical theft. If printed and left on desk, cleaner/visitor can steal them. Store in safe or locked drawer.
Voice Match (Biometric) used to permit personal results/payments. Not high assurance (replay/recording risk).
Push notification that wakes up the App in background to check signals/location without alerting user UI.
Payload encrypted. Apple/Google push service cannot read the OTP/Challenge content. Only the App can decrypt.
Specifying if PIN is required for a key operation. 'never', 'once' (per session), 'always' (per sig).
Specifying if physical touch is required. 'always' (default), 'never' (automated/unattended - risky), 'cached'.
Proprietary OTP protocol. Key generates a 44-char modhex string (ID + Counter + MAC) on touch. USB Keyboard emulation.
Encoding used by Yubico. Uses characters 'cbdefghijklnrtuv' which are keyboard-layout independent (QWERTY/DVORAK safe).
Storing a long complex password on the key. Emulates keyboard to type it. Useful for legacy legacy systems.
Used for KeePass/macOS login. PC sends challenge, Key computes response (HMAC-SHA1). No user input needed.
PIV = Smart Card standard (x.509 certs). FIDO = Web Auth. YubiKey supports both. PIV used for Code Signing/Legacy Wireless.
A digital certificate embedded in a hardware key during manufacturing. Chains to the Vendor's CA. Proves authenticity.
Uses electrical current to map the ridges and valleys. Harder to spoof with a photo than Optical scanners.
Takes a 2D photo of the finger. Vulnerable to high-res photos or latent prints. Common in older devices.
Uses sound waves to map 3D pores and ridges. Works through wet/dirty fingers. Very secure (Qualcomm).
Presenting a fake trait (Mask, Photo, Voice Recording) to the sensor to bypass auth.
Mechanisms (Liveness check, 3D depth, texture analysis) to detect and block Presentation Attacks.
Synthetic partial fingerprint that matches a high percentage of population (like '1234' for passwords). Exploits small sensors.
Very High. Vein patterns are internal and invisible. Requires live blood flow (IR absorption) to be read.
Can often be unlocked with a printed photo or video of the user. Not suitable for payments.
Iris patterns are extremely entropy-rich and stable over life. Hard to capture without cooperation (unlike face).
Third-party agents (Duo, Okta) can cache 'offline verification' data (e.g. HOTP check locally) to allow login on planes.
Direct UDP connection for RDP. MFA is handled at the Gateway/Broker level (Azure AD) before connection is established.
Central point to enforce MFA for all RDP connections. Prevents exposing RDP (3389) to internet directly.
Azure feature that forces user to use their STRONGEST registered method (e.g. Push) instead of weaker ones (SMS).
Deprecated by Microsoft. New deployments must use Azure MFA (Cloud). Existing ones migrating.
Deploy Multiple NPS servers behind a Load Balancer. Azure MFA is stateless. If one NPS fails, others handle reqs.
MFA (Push/Call) takes time. VPN/Radius timeouts must be increased (e.g. to 60s) to preventing giving up before user approves.
Allowing requests from specific IPs (e.g. HQ) to skip MFA. Convenient, but risks IP spoofing or internal threats.
Skipping MFA if user is on the corporate network (Intranet claim). Relies on perimeter security (Zero Trust opposes this).
User logs in with Pwd (Low assurance). App requests high-value resource. IdP returns 'interaction_required'. App sends user back to IdP for MFA.
Logs should show: Method used (SMS/App), Result (Success/Deny), Location, Device ID. Essential for forensics.
Tracing ID shared between App, IdP, and MFA provider logs to debug a specific failed attempt across systems.

q: Why MFA fails on Legacy Mail Apps?
o: Legacy protocols (POP/IMAP/SMTP) cannot show a web pop-up for MFA or processing Challenges. Require App Pwd or Modern Auth.
Protocol (OIDC/SAML) that supports Redirect flows, enabling MFA prompts inside client apps (Outlook Mobile).
Critical step. Attackers use Legacy Auth (Password Spray) to bypass MFA policies. Disable at tenant level.
Testing a policy (e.g. 'Block Legacy Auth') without impacting users. Logs 'What would have happened'. Safe rollout.
Simulating a login (User X from IP Y) to see which Conditional Access policies would apply. Troubleshooting helper.
SSSD can be configured to prompt for MFA (via PAM) against an IdP/LDAP or local TOTP.
Specifically adds Duo MFA to SSH, `su`, and console logins. Uses `login_duo` or PAM module.
Requiring admin to tap YubiKey (or phone) every time they run a privileged command. Prevents malware from using cached sudo rights.
Storing PGP private keys on the hardware device. Used for signing Git Commits or encrypting emails securely.
Standard for storing PGP keys on smart cards. YubiKey implements this standard via USB/NFC.
Dependent on device storage. YubiKey 5 supports ~25-100. once full, must delete old ones.
Must be done via Credential Management API (Browser/OS). Cannot be done by the RP (Server) remotely.
Policy ensuring user CANNOT skip FIDO setup. If they don't have a key, they can't login.
Some high-security keys (e.g. IronKey) wipe data after N failed PIN attempts.
High security certification. Requires Tamper Evidence and Tamper Resistance (Zeroization if opened) for hardware.
Compliance requirement. Must use Validated Cryptography module. Standard YubiKeys are not FIPS certified (separate series).
Trade-off: Security vs Usability vs Cost. FIDO (Best Security, High Cost). App (Good Security, Low Cost). SMS (Poor Security, Low Cost).
Teaching users: 'Never approve a notification you didn't trigger', 'Check the URL', 'Don't share codes'.
Strict protocol to verify user identities over phone (e.g. Verify Manager, Callback, Push Auth) before resetting MFA.
Short-lived code generated by Admin to let user login if phone is lost. Must be given securely (Voice).
Use Backup Codes or Alternate Method (Email/Office Phone) to log in and register new device. Reduces Helpdesk load.
Admin registers Serial Number of keys to users BEFORE shipping. User just plugs in and works. High security distribution.
Very low range (<4cm). Attack requires physical proximity. Minimal risk compared to remote.
Password managers autofill passwords (phishable on fake sites). WebAuthn keys REFUSE to sign on fake domains.
Biometrics are public (Face/Fingerprints left everywhere). They Identify you. They shouldn't be the ONLY secret.
Technique to distort biometric data reversibly so if database is stolen, you can 'change' your fingerprint mapping.
Active: Ask user to 'Blink' or 'Turn head'. Passive: Analyze skin texture/micro-movements without user knowing.
Replay attacks (recording user) or synthesized voice (AI). Anti-spoofing requires challenge phrases or liveness (tone variation).
Historically low (<30% for optional). Enforcement (Mandatory) is usually required to achieve safety.
Bots triggering thousands of SMS OTPs to premium numbers (owned by attackers) to drain company budget.
Rate Limiting, Captcha before sending SMS, Geo-blocking high-risk countries.
APIs use Access Tokens. MFA happens during token issuance (OAuth Flow). API itself validates the 'amr' claim.
Array in JWT (e.g. ['pwd', 'mfa', 'fido']) showing HOW the user authenticated. RS checks this for sensitive actions.
Check 'amr'. If 'mfa' missing -> Return 401/403 with 'insufficient_scope' or error requiring step-up.
Abstract value (Gold, Silver, Bronze) indicating security level. Mapped to specific methods by IdP.
Single Factor (Password). Provides little to no assurance against phishing/replay.
Session where user can view data but not edit/export unless they perform Step-up MFA.
Periodic (e.g. quarterly) review of who has MFA exemptions or Admin rights. Compliance requirement.
Basic Auth sends credentials in Header (Base64). It prevents MFA prompts (no interactive capability). Attackers love it.
Sending fake phishing emails to employees. If they click/enter creds, they get 'Teachable Moment' training.
Cloud service (APNS/FCM) delivers a message to the specific device token. App wakes up to handle it.

q: Why is Push better than OTP?
o: User Experience. One tap 'Approve' vs reading 6 digits and typing. Also cryptographically bound to the App installation.
Difficult. Often requires appending OTP to password field (Pwd+OTP) or using a Gateway proxy.
Microsoft Account allows passwordless setup (App Sign-in) or Windows Hello. Local Accounts don't support cloud MFA easily.
MacOS supports Smart Card (PIV) login natively. TouchID is local biometric auth.
Model of YubiKey with a fingerprint sensor. Authenticates user ON THE KEY. works on any PC (driverless).
Using NFC card (YubiKey/SmartCard) to tap phone/reader for instant auth. High speed for hospitals/retail.
PC unlocks when User's Phone is near (Bluetooth RSSI). Convenience feature (Dynamic Lock), low security assurance.
Webcam monitoring if user is still present. If user walks away or second face appears, locks screen privacy.
Always authenticate and authorize based on all available data points (Identity, Device, Location) for EVERY request.
Rules defining a 'managed' device (Encrypted, Password Set, OS Updated). Used as a condition for Access (MFA alternative or addition).
Syncing On-Prem AD users to Cloud (Azure AD). Cloud handles MFA. On-prem apps use Cloud via App Proxy.
Syncing hash of password to Cloud. Allows Cloud to authenticate user directly (and enforce MFA) without calling back to on-prem.
Cloud Agent verifies password against On-Prem AD in real-time. Cloud still handles MFA prompt.
On-prem ADFS handles the MFA (via adapter) before issuing token to Cloud. Complex infrastructure.
Moving from On-Prem MFA Server to Cloud Azure MFA. Requires re-registering users or migrating MFA settings via utility.
Uploading a CSV file (Serial Number, Secret Key) to the IdP to register hardware tokens in bulk.
Server adjusts the acceptance window for specific user based on successful logins to account for clock drift.
Accounts with complex long passwords stored in physical safe. No MFA/Phone attached. Only for 'Site Down' scenarios.
If the MFA service (Cloud/Phone Network) goes down, you need a way to log in to fix it or reroute traffic.
Critical. Alert immediately (SMS/Email) if the emergency account signs in. Investigate instantly.
Just-In-Time membership to a Group (e.g. 'Domain Admins'). User is added only after MFA + Approval.
Using Application Proxy or VPN to enforce Cloud MFA on legacy internal web apps (Intranet).
App Proxy injects user identity into HTTP Header after MFA. Legacy app trusts the header.
Allows a service (Proxy) to impersonate a user to a backend service (SQL/File) after frontend MFA. Protocol transition.
If PIN entered wrong 3-8 times, key locks. Resetting key WIPES all credentials (anti-bruteforce).
Common WebAuthn attestation format. Contains signature and certificate chain efficiently.
Proof that the key is generated inside the computer's TPM (Trusted Platform Module). Windows Hello uses this.
Proof that the key is in Android Hardware Keystore (TEE/StrongBox).
Requiring GPG signing (key on hardware token) for every git commit. Proves developer identity.
Mandatory for all Root/IAM users. AWS Console/Azure Portal access controls critical infra.
Use temporary credentials (STS) obtained after MFA (GetSessionToken). Long-term keys shouldn't be used.
Tool to securely store AWS credentials in OS Keychain and handle MFA/STS session rotation automatically.
Opens browser for interactive login. Supports MFA/FIDO natively. Token cached.
They can't do MFA. Use Workload Identity Federation or Certificate-based auth + Conditional Access IP restriction.
VPN Server supports 'Challenge/Response'. User enters Pwd -> Prompt 'Enter Code' -> User enters OTP.
User enters Pwd. Radius server pauses. Triggers Push. User hits 'Approve'. Radius sends 'Access-Accept'. Seamless.
Conditional Access control requiring specific STRENGTH (e.g. 'Phishing Resistant MFA') for high-risk apps.
Admins can view registered keys, enforce attestation, and block specific models (AAGUIDs) via policy.
Passkeys synced via Cloud (iCloud/Google) roam to all user devices instantly. High convenience.
Passkey that CANNOT leave the device (TPM/SE). Higher security (resembles hardware token).
List (usb, nfc, ble, internal) helping browser show correct UI (e.g. 'Touch ID' vs 'Insert Key').
Allows key to output a shared secret for offline usage (e.g. encrypting disk/offline login) derived from salt.
Allows storing arbitrary data (certificates/encoded data) on the key. Useful for SSH certs.
Small blob stored alongside credential. Supplied to RP during Assert. Good for per-credential settings.

q: Why MFA on Email is critical?
o: Email is the 'Master Key'. Password resets for all other services go to Email. Compromised Email = Total Compromise.
MFA stops most BEC attacks (where attacker logins to read invoice emails). Legacy Auth bypass is the main weakness.
Attacker app asks for 'Read Mail' permission. User grants access (OAuth). MFA doesn't stop this (User authenticated correctly).
Blocking users from granting consent to apps. Users must 'Request Admin Approval'. Prevents Consent Phishing.
Requiring SMS/OTP verification before user can digitally sign a DocuSign contract. Proves signer identity.
Highest legal level (eIDAS). Requires face-to-face ID proofing + Secure Signature Device (Tokens) + MFA.
Remote verification where agent checks user's ID card via video call. Used to onboard for High Assurance MFA.
NFC requires <4cm (Intentional). BLE ranges meters (Risk of accidental connection/tracking). NFC preferred for high sec.
Encrypting a private key with another key (KEK). Used in HSMs and FIDO keys (Handle is wrapped key).
Tamper-resistant chip (in phone/card) storing crypto data. Isolated from OS main processor. Hard to hack.
Secure area of the main processor (ARM TrustZone) ensuring code/data loaded inside is protected. Used for Biometrics.
KeyStore implementation running on a dedicated Secure Element (Titan M chip). Higher security than TEE.
Dedicated coprocessor for crypto operations (TouchID/FaceID). Keys never leave it. OS requests ops, gets result.
FIDO standards ensure one key works across Google, Microsoft, Facebook, etc. Eliminates proprietary silos.
The website/application identifying itself (rpId) and requesting authentication.
Platform (Built-in: TouchID) vs Cross-Platform (Roaming: YubiKey). RP can request specific types.
Concept where attestation proves properties of the key, allowing server to trust the key's security promises.
Extension returning HOW user verified (Fingerprint, Pin, Pattern) to the server for audit/policy.
L1 (Basic) to L3+ (Hardware protection). Helps RPs decide which authenticators to accept.
Admins hold the keys to the kingdom. One compromised admin = Game Over. 100% MFA required.
Accounts with indirect admin rights (e.g. can reset Admin passwords). Must be protected with MFA like Admins.
Users should not be permament Admins. Use PIM/JIT. MFA is the gate for elevating to Admin.
Microsoft states MFA blocks 99.9% of account compromise attacks.
Passwordless (FIDO2/Passkeys). Eliminating the Phishable factor (Password) entirely.
Ensuring device is Healthy, Managed, and Patch before granting access. MFA + Device State = High Assurance.
Critical. If MFA is too hard, users find workarounds (Shared accounts). Biometrics/SSO improve UX.
If 5 people share an Admin account, who holds the Phone? Leads to OTP sharing (unsafe). Use Named Accounts.
Service accounts cannot interact with MFA prompts. Must use Certs/Keys and IP restrictions instead.
Identity for Azure Resources (VM/Function). No password to manage. Auto-rotated. Very secure (No MFA needed).
Identity for containers/pods (Kubernetes). Federates with OIDC. No long-lived secrets.
Detecting anomalous behavior by internal users (Data exfiltration). Triggers MFA/Lockout.
Users should be able to kill sessions on other devices (Revoke Refresh Tokens) if they suspect theft.
Dashboard where users can see 'My Sign-ins' and 'My Devices'. Empower users to spot hacks.
Email/Push: 'New login from Device X'. If not you, click here to lock. Fast response loop.
Biometric data is 'Special Category'. Requires explicit consent. On-device processing (TouchID) reduces GDPR scope vs Server-side.
Illinois law. Strict rules on collecting/storing biometrics. Huge fines for violations.
Ensuring MFA logs/phone numbers stay within region (EU). US CLOUD Act considerations.
Using premium rate numbers for SMS/Voice MFA. Attackers drain billing accounts.
